title: 115_hr66
content: The Act may be cited as the "Route 66 Centennial Commission Act". Route 66, the first all-paved highway in the U.S. connecting the Midwest to California, played a significant role in American history. It symbolized opportunity for many during the Great Depression, provided employment, and was crucial for transporting troops and supplies during World War II. Route 66, a key route for troops returning home in 1945, symbolized the nation's optimism during the postwar economic recovery. It became an icon of independence, connecting people across the U.S. The tourist industry along Route 66 flourished, leading to the growth of various businesses. Despite being decommissioned in 1985, Route 66's popularity has continued to grow domestically and internationally. A commission is proposed to study and commemorate the road's centennial anniversary in 2026. A commission should be established to study and recommend activities to celebrate Route 66's centennial anniversary in 2026. Establishment of the Route 66 Centennial Commission to oversee activities for the celebration of Route 66's centennial anniversary in 2026. The Commission's duties include studying and recommending activities to honor Route 66's centennial anniversary, planning a conference on the U.S. Numbered Highway System, and assisting in related activities. The Commission, composed of 19 members appointed by the President and Governors of Illinois and Missouri, includes qualified citizens described in subsection (b). The Commission consists of 19 members appointed by the President and Governors of Illinois and Missouri, including qualified citizens from Kansas, Oklahoma, Texas, New Mexico, and Arizona. The Commission consists of 19 members appointed by the President and Governors of Illinois and Missouri, including qualified citizens from various states. The members are appointed based on recommendations from different officials and must be private citizens dedicated to educating others about historical figures and events. The Commission consists of 19 members appointed by the President and Governors of Illinois and Missouri, including qualified citizens from various states. Members are appointed based on recommendations and must have substantial knowledge of Route 66. Initial appointments must be made within 120 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve for the life of the Commission without pay. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission may appoint a Director and additional personnel as needed. The Director may be appointed without following certain civil service laws, while the staff must adhere to these laws for appointments and pay. The Commission may appoint a Director and additional personnel as needed, with the Director being appointed without following certain civil service laws. The staff must adhere to these laws for appointments and pay, specifically in subchapter III of chapter 53 of that title relating to classification and General Schedule pay rates. The Commission is granted powers. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can obtain necessary information from US departments or agencies and use the US mails for official purposes. The Commission can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis to carry out its responsibilities under this Act. SEC. 8. REPORTS. The Commission may submit interim reports to Congress. Within 5 years of enactment, a comprehensive report with recommendations for Route 66 centennial commemoration will be submitted to the President and Congress. Recommendations will include financial and administrative responsibilities allocation among public and private entities. Activities like production and publication may also be recommended. The Commission's activities include producing and distributing educational materials, organizing conferences and programs, developing projects for libraries and museums, and holding ceremonies to commemorate specific events related to Route 66. The Commission's activities include producing educational materials, organizing programs, and holding ceremonies to commemorate events related to Route 66. The Commission will also issue commemorative items such as coins, medals, certificates, and stamps. A final report will be submitted to the President and Congress before the Commission's termination. The Secretary of Transportation, in consultation with Governors, will prepare a plan on Route 66 preservation needs. A report will be submitted to Congress within 3 years. The Commission will terminate by June 30, 2027, with no additional funds authorized for the Act's requirements. The House of Representatives passed the Act on July 16, 2018. Karen L. Haas attested to it.
